title: How to Charge Your iPhone with an Unofficial Lightning Cable

steps.title: Search for an MFi-certified cable.
steps.content: Search for an MFi-certified cable. MFi (Made For iDevices) cables are certified by Apple to work with your iOS device, even if they aren't made by Apple itself. MFi-certified cables will not cause your iOS device to stop charging when you use them. While MFi cables are cheaper than Apple cables, they still aren't inexpensive.

steps.title: Look for the "Made for" certification.
steps.content: Look for the "Made for" certification. This box will be somewhere on the packaging of the cable you're trying to purchase; it will say "Made for" followed by the iOS devices it supports (e.g., iPhone, iPad, iPod) and their respective silhouettes. If you don't see "MFi" in the title of the cable and the "Made for" certification somewhere in the packaging, the cable won't work with your iPhone. If you're shopping online and can't see the packaging, consider emailing the provider for more information.

steps.title: Look at user reviews.
steps.content: Look at user reviews. If recent reviews mention that the cable stopped working for a new release of iOS, the cable probably won't work. In a traditional retail store, simply ask to talk to the tech department or customer service.

steps.title: Look up the MFi cable's serial number.
steps.content: Look up the MFi cable's serial number. If you see positive reviews outside of the site or store in which you found the cable, you should go ahead and purchase it. Otherwise, keep looking for an MFi-certified cable. Some MFi cables that worked with one version of iOS cease working when your iPhone updates. For this reason, try to purchase a cable manufactured recently.

steps.title: Plug the cable into your iPhone.
steps.content: Plug the cable into your iPhone. If the cable is truly unsupported, you should see the following message pop up on the screen: "This cable or accessory is not certified and may not work reliably with this iPhone."

steps.title: Tap OK.
steps.content: Tap OK . Doing so will excuse the message.

steps.title: Press and hold the Lock button.
steps.content: Press and hold the Lock button. After a few seconds, a slider will appear at the top of the screen with the message "slide to power off" displayed.

steps.title: Slide the switch right.
steps.content: Slide the switch right. It's at the top of the screen. Doing so will power down your phone; in some cases, your phone will begin charging while it's off because the software restrictions that prevent the cable from being recognized are no longer in effect.

steps.title: Turn on your phone after ten minutes.
steps.content: Turn on your phone after ten minutes. To do so, simply hold down the Lock button until the white Apple icon appears on the screen. If your iPhone's battery life has increased at all, turn your iPhone back off and let it charge for the next couple of hours. Depending on your iPhone's operating system and the cable type, this method may not work. If so, you'll need to buy an MFi-certified cable .
